awd_titl_txt: EAGER: SaTC: Early-Stage Interdisciplinary Collaboration: Collaborative: A Sociotechnical Metrics Framework for Network and Security Operations Centers
awd_abstract_narration:
Network and Security Operations Centers (SOCs) are central components of modern enterprise networks. SOCs manage network operations, defend against cyber threats, and maintain regulatory compliance. Typically, management and SOC operators use monitoring software and metrics, such as open and closed tickets, to manage SOC efficiency. These metrics may fail to represent the real effectiveness of the SOC and the security posture of the network. This project will study how improved metrics could better incentivize productive routines, reveal potentially fundamental security vulnerabilities in the network, and trigger stabilizing right-sizing processes in the controlling organization. The project will afford an opportunity for students to participate in research on security operations and thereby encourage careers in security research or professions.

This project will develop a new metrics framework that measures and validates SOC performance against enterprise network security. The specific goal is to create a framework that SOCs and parent organization personnel could use to create tailored metrics for their unique security environment. The research includes a technical study of network monitoring, as well as a qualitative approach to the study of organizational environments that analyzes people and technological artifacts as interacting components in complex systems and describes stability and change in the functioning or mis-functioning of these systems. By treating networks, security components, and operations staff as part of an interdependent system, the metrics will be able to account for factors such as outstanding security vulnerabilities, strategic and long-term planning, and constituency interests, and will provide on-the-ground SOC analysts with ways to input local knowledge into higher-up decisions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Organizations use Security Operations Centers (SOCs) to defend against cyber threats and manage their network operations. SOCs use metrics frameworks to monitor networks, prioritize tasks, and communicate network facts to management. Metrics sit between the network and the SOC, and the SOC and management. SOC metrics are often deficient at linking these components together, especially the security posture of the network and the SOC. These metrics lead to inefficiencies and maladaptive behavior on the part of the SOC analysts and degrade enterprise network security. 

This project was a collaborative effort and focused on developing a new metrics framework that harmonizes SOC performance against enterprise network security by treating the SOC as an integrated part of the network itself. The researchers collaborated with different SOCs and were also embedded in one of these environments for 3 years (2019-2022) working side by side with SOC security analysts. The researchers witnessed, documented, and analyzed the transition to COVID-19 work-from-home and then back to in-office activities. In the last part of the project, the researchers proposed a framework for tailored metrics that is being integrated in one of the collaborating SOCs. The integration results are being monitored. 

Overall, the project adopted a multi-faceted effort involving approaches from computer science and science&technology studies that enabled the researchers to take initiatives as they saw problems and as the situation changed. For instance, while aiming at understanding the real-world interactions between SOC personnel, and their (organizational and technical) environment, challenges noticed in collaborating SOCs and discussions with security analysts triggered two parallel research projects: a project focused on defensive technologies employed by activists and a project aiming at understanding the updating ecosystem for Android devices. At first these efforts moved away from the core of SOC metrics research; however, relevant findings and observations were brought back into the SOC environment (e.g., practices for protecting regular user privacy, features for labeling 'outdated' Android devices, etc.). 

The research findings were validated by different communities and resulted in three peer-reviewed publications (two cybersecurity conferences and a magazine) and a presentation in the Special Interest Group in Computing, Information, and Society conference. Moreover, the project trained two graduate students, three undergraduate students, and included multiple collaborators from industry and academia. The perspectives and backgrounds of the involved researchers were diverse and included various underrepresented groups such as Native-American, African-American, Asian-American, and female researchers.
